Holy hell man, why not use a validation library or at least write a reusable function?

@user1839308 your code snippet *is* using `eval`.   And there is no triple equality check.  Your evaluation will be akin to taking the result of `documnet.getElementById('searchRecord6').value == qbd_numrows` which is either `true` or `false`  and then taking that value and comparing it against 0.  So therefore your `if` statement will evaluate to true iff `documnet.getElementById('searchRecord6').value != qbd_numrows`, since `false == 0` is `true` in javascript thanks to loose typing.
Side note, use [triple equals](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/359494/javascript-vs-does-it-matter-which-equal-operator-i-use) to avoid loose typing
Another issue, you have a semi-colon after your first `if` statement.  Therefore all the code in your block will always get run, regardless if `qdb_numrows` is 0 or not.

URL parameters cannot inject javascript.  It doesn't sound like you have any ability to run javascript in A or B.  FYI, when A and B are different domains, you can't use javascript from one to act on the other either because of same-origin security restrictions in the browser.  It sounds like you need modifications to page B so that it will load a view based on a URL parameter.

What is wrong with the inferred type - which is precisely `Content ∈ fs => Rec Attr fs -> LanguageContent`? This type is much more descriptive than `HasContent a => a -> LanguageContent`. If you really want the latter, define a class `class HasContent a where getContent :: a -> LanguageContent` and an instance `instance (Content ∈ rs) => HasContent (Rec Attr rs) where ...`. If you plan to have other instances, this approach has merit, but if this is the only instance, just use the function as-is.
There are quite a few functions which all have the same constraint, and I don't want to repeat it everywhere.

It's not strictly proper to integrate answers into the question. If you want to include bits from the answers @user2407038 and I provided, please explain what you're doing in the answer so that the conversation doesn't become confusing.

Also, referring to `rs` in the type `(c ~ Rec Attr rs, Content ∈ rs)` as a "phantom parameter" is unhelpful. In fully monomorphic code, `rs` will be specialized to a specific, concrete, meaningful value representing the fields or rows of the record.

Looking at your diagram, you I think you are limiting a rider to only one bus at a time.  For a rider to be on many buses, you will have to duplicate all of rider data.  Not a good design decision.  This is a many-to-many relationship - a rider can take many buses, a bus can have many riders.

From the screenshot it looks like you are trying to display ID of the relation. If you have two models(tables) like Employee and Manager or you have self-referenced Employee model(table) then you can just add prefetch for your datasource. In this case you will be able to bind Manager Id like this: @datasource.item.Manager.Id. Docs: https://developers.google.com/appmaker/models/datasources#prefetch
Since it's an SQL view it doesn't have a relation, so I have to query by hand =)

In this case, If the table is view-only, I would suggest using calculated datasource instead. This will reduce number of calls to server and database, so you'll improve overall page performance and get rid off labels blinking. With current implementation, for table with N rows app will make at least (N + 1 calls to server) + (N + 1 calls to database). With calculated datasource you will reduce it to 1 + 1 = 2 calls.
I had the same scenario before. What I did is created a setInterval function that reload the datasource every x minutes. Perhaps that can help.

Some more things: you need to use a valid `from` value. If your Zoho email address is `abc123@zoho.com`, it won't let you send from `noreply@mydomain.com`. If your email is `noreply@mydomain.com`, it won't let you send from `abc123@mydomain.com`, or anything that isn't aliased to the address you're sending from.

As stated in this [thread](https://stackoverflow.com/a/6095695/5832311), you are likely getting this error because somewhere in your code, you are calling a function which in turn calls another function and so forth, until you hit the call stack limit. In order to fix it, ensure that your recursive function has a base case which is able to be met. Also, this [thread](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/37398722/exceeded-maximum-stack-depth-in-a-custom-function-for-google-sheets#comment62309499_37398722) also suggested to avoid recursion (using a loop).

So, using the MDS Excel plug-in as a front end to just any sql server table will not work quite the way you want.  MDS will create a database full of tables according to the architecture of your MDS data model, and you can update your data warehouse from those tables.  MDS has a lot of functionality that you won't use, but you'll need to understand and handle when you write those transfers.  Getting it to work in near real time will probably take some effort too.  Personally, I think you're going to be trading Excel headaches for MDS headaches, but what you describe is at least imaginable.

You shoudn't catch that exception. Remove the try cacth completely, and instead **avoid** the exception by fixing your code and avoiding to access invalid indices. `strArray[i][j+1]`, for example, tries to access index j+1. When value of j is 4, j+1 is thus 5, which is an invalid index since your array only has 5 elements (and indices thus go from 0 to 4).

ScaryWombat changing the loop to 3 didn't work.. @JBNizet, without the try-catch, i'm able to get the output along with the exception and i understand why it's coming.. I don't know how to fix the code like tell it not to look for the index j+1 i.e,5 when j is 4
In that case your logic is wrong - step through your code with a debugger and find the error

@ScaryWombat there is no error in the code.. there is only the array out of bound exception caused because of exactly what JB Nizet said. when the compiler finds the second T in (welcome"T"ozohocorpora"T"ion) it's looking for i+1 which is out of the array, hence the exception occurs

@Shravan I won't write the code for you (I don't know what it's supposed to do anyway). But Java has `if` statements. So you can test the value of i` and `j` before accessing an index that would be invalid. loops have bounds, too, so you can fix the bounds of loops to avoid accessing invalid indices. Accessing invalid indices causing such an exception IS is huge error in the code. Your code has bugs that need to be fixed, not worked around.

The definition of the pattern synonym seems fine; it's type is wrong. The types of pattern synonyms are not really types at all (in particular, pattern synonym type annotations must specify which constraints are proved by matching on the pattern - your type definition says *no* constraints are proved, but the inlined pattern match is a GADT; by pattern matching on it you prove `rs1 ~ '[ x :-> xs ]` for some `x, xs`). A description of pattern synonym type annotations is given [here](https://downloads.haskell.org/~ghc/latest/docs/html/users_guide/glasgow_exts.html#typing-of-pattern-synonyms).

Thank you; that link is very enlightening. I'm still having a hard time figuring out what proved constraint I need to add in this case, however. rs1 doesn't appear anywhere in the pattern declaration so adding `rs1 ~ '[ x :-> xs ]` doesn't constrain anything.

I was referring to the `rs1` in the type of `f` - indeed, the appropriate change would add a new variable to the pattern signature. I believe something like `() => (rs ~ '[s :-> t]) => Sing s -> Sing t -> SList rs` should work (but I can't compile the example myself to make sure).
That did it! I'm still not really clear on why my original type signature doesn't imply the new constraint. Anyway, if you want to lift your comment into an answer, I will accept it. Thanks!

Short answer is, yes it is possible. However, it involves a lot of scripting depending on how many filters you can apply on your datasource. Then you have to add parameters to your datasource and set those parameters equal to your filters via a client script. From your client script you pass those parameters to a server script and set your filters on the server script again to filter your model and then you can create a spreadsheet using SpreadsheetApp service. Since you are already using the createMode datasource, I believe the "Create" button saves the record. You can just simply open the on click event editor and add `widget.datasource.item.TotalRate = textbox4value`, or whatever the field is called for TotalRate, before the line that creates the item.

Other possibility would be to bind the textbox value to your datasource item and for the onValueChange or onValueEdit event of your other two textboxes set your item.TotalRate. In this case I would also suggest to set your TextBox4 to 'ViewOnlyIfDissabled' and then in the property editor uncheck 'enabled'.

I believe calculated models do have a loading state, although it may only apply when `datasource.load()` is called.  As for the datasource, suggest box uses whatever datasource it inherits.  So your suggest box probably uses one of your calculated model's datasources and whichever one you've set in the parent widget.  This could be the default datasource (which is named after the model it inherits) or it could be one that you explicitly define.

Refer to [this](https://developers.google.com/appmaker/images/model/DataSourceLifeCycle.png) image which leads me to believe that only the `load` function triggers `datasource.loading` and `datasource.loaded`.  To my understanding query filters are calculated and applied client side although this might be totally and completely incorrect and applying filters may very well change the loading state of a datasource.  I would suggest setting up a simple test which constantly outputs `datasource.loading` while changing query filters on calculated models to make sure.

Sounds like you should write a simple label-based timing scheme, e.g. `function start(label) { db[label] = new Date().getTime(); } function stop(label) { const now = new Date().getTime(); const then = db[label]; return then ? now - then : 0; }`

Pull the resultset without the calculated field (opening balance) into a temporary table (sorted by GL account). Then loop through the table, storing the closing balance to a variable. So your rowsData functionsQuery[1] specifically points to the second record of the functions query. ChildIndex will always return a number and refers to the nth element inside a parent element. So your first attempt probably returns 4 since the button is the 5th element in the table row but since index starts with 0 it is 4. The second attempt returns the index of the row relative to its parent which is a list element. If you want to just return the the Certificate_ID I would suggest using widget.datasource.item.Certificate_ID. That will actuallly point to a value from your data vs just an index of an element.

If you introduced a label into each row and set its value binding to widget.parent.childIndex then it would correctly show 0 in the first row. So pretty much any other type of code besides console.log() would correctly identify the first row childIndex as 0.

A few things to consider. If you apply a filter client side when changing your tabs you would want to clear your filters via datasource.query.clearFilters(), then set the new filter and then reload the datasource via datasource.load(). This would still take a moment however and introduce what you described as 'lag' in the UI. I believe what you describe in your last paragraph 'it doesn't seem to be changing the displayed data' is because you don't reload your datasource. Alternative, create a separate datasource for each tab and filter the results on the server and autoload the data.

Regarding the map size, you may want to investigate how is created the map container. It could be that it didn't reach its final size when the map itself is created. Theoretically, if you trigger a map resize (`map.getViewPort().resize()`) when the container has the size you need, the map should occupy the whole container space

Presumably your 'Contract' has the same language for everyone that may be filling out the information via the text boxes? If that is the case you can set up a Google Docs template with all the text of the contract and everywhere you will need a textbox field entered into the document you can create a placeholder like '<<MyTextboxField>>'. Just by looking at your code real quick I'd say your problem is here ss.getSheetByName("Report").getRange(3, 1).setValue(user); At least initially it appears that you overwrite the same cell value with each user submission, therefore, before you call your UrlFetchApp your cell value may have already been changed because of a concurrent user session. You would be better off creating a new spreadsheet with each submission, converting it to PDF and then using the Drive API to delete the created spreadsheet. In that case you could set up a template and make a copy instead and replacing cell values

Maybe I'm not understanding something, but you say sending the email is step 5, yet you list it as a function before you even write the data to your copied spreadsheet. To execute functions from within another function you need to list your additional functions outside of your main function. So you should first write your function email(), then writeData(), then your main function createDoc(). In fact you would be best off just writing your data within your createDoc function, then create your pdf at the very end and then passing your pdf to a separate email function or doing that at the end.

Do keep in mind that widget visibility settings are not considered to be secure. You will want to set your model security settings whether data will be loaded based on roles or what not. At the UI level the only thing that is considered to be secure is if you set your page security settings because that will be checked against the server. But any widget visibility binding is a client side setting and therefore could be surpassed by someone that knows what they are doing.

so how do I check if the last item of the Grid has been loaded or how do I point it to the last datasource item of the grid?

Lets say your datasource for the grid is MyDatasource1. Then you would simply do if(app.datasources.MyDatasource1.loaded) { //your function if true }. However, if you already loaded that datasource due to some other process, then this would not work. The better way to do this would be to reload the datasource in your process and then call this script: app.datasources.MyDatasource1.load(function() { app.closeDialog(); }); this would then close your dialog after successfully loading your datasource.

I think the main draw back you may have with App Maker is that your students would need to have an email address within the same domain as where the application is published from. Additionally, if using Google Cloud SQL as your database then there will be some additional charges incurred. However, you could bypass Cloud SQL and just set a data model to a calculated model, which will call your server script connecting to the spreadsheet. Otherwise, I think for something as simple as grades updating and viewing by students the learning curve would not be steep at all.

Do you have a single screen in your app? The expressions in the OnVisible property of a screen will only be executed when the screen is shown - either when the app is being opened, or when you navigate from another screen. If that's the case, try adding a new screen, then toggling (in the tree view on the left) between the two screens, and you should get the OnVisible expressions executed.

There would be multiple ways of getting this accomplished. I would consider having either a relation item or field associated with each item in your initial list and then having your form/pagefragment/separatepage or what ever show based on the list item click. For example: your first list item is supposed to bring up the form for family history, so have a relation to family history and in your list row onclick event have widget.root.PageFragments[widget.datasource.item.YourRelationItem].visible = true;  The same would be true for different pages or just form widgets.

I had thought of this as well.  In this situation, the document components would be different for each document type and even a specified document may change over time.  I am trying to see if there were a way to not have the user interface be static so that it can accommodate ongoing changes to existing document types as well as provide for a user correctly accessing older document types that have been deprecated.  For example, if I had a patient that came for services 3 years ago, their intake form may be different than the form developed for this year and I need to be able to access it.
My thought was that the visible/invisible approach might make the page become unwieldy over time?

The dynamic page content is definetely possible, however since it sounds like a lot of your items are going to be based on hard data, the models really are not dynamic, so you really can't build in dynamic data at run time for example. Rather than visible/invisible properties I might suggest navigating to different pages instead and maybe having many-to-many relations to your list item and if your list item has OldFamilyHistory and NewFamilyHistory data relations incorporate a popup to select which page you may want to navigate to.

For AM specifically, when adding a new script file it will let you choose Client or Server script and then that particular script file will run on client or server. Since AM runs via Google Apps Script any interaction where you specifically call a server function it needs to be initiated from the client by calling google.scripts.run(YourServerFunction()). You are able to have the same function name in a server script and client script, however you cannot have two functions called the same on either server or client scripts. All model events run on the server. Is that what you are asking?

Yes there is. You'll have to use the [REST api](https://developers.google.com/drive/api/v3/reference/)  with the [UrlFetchApp](https://developers.google.com/apps-script/reference/url-fetch/url-fetch-app) class.

In that case I would say to decide based on either how secure your script operation needs to be or if your script needs to work on records currently loaded in the client or a larger set of records. Server scripts are generally more secure compared to client scripts, so therefore if only certain roles or individuals are allowed to perform the script then I would select a server script. Also, if your datasource only loads 25 records but you need to perform an operation on all records from a model then also choose server script.

Your third paragraph, where you open a page with datasource inherited 'Action', you should set that page datasource to 'Incident' instead. Couple of things to keep straight. Model events are only triggered if the action was called from the client, you can make a call back to the client when the server model event finished by using `widget.datasource.createItem({success: function(record) { console.log(record.id + ' was created'); }, failure: function(error) { console.log(error.message);}});` for example. The same is true for client functions `.deleteItem()` or `.saveChanges()` (however for saveChanges the datasource needs to be manual save).

If you use `google.script.run` from the client to initiate a server function then you would use `google.script.run.withSuccessHandler(YourClientSuccessFunction).withFailureHandler(YourClientFailureFunction).YourServerFunction()`. If you are referring to the model onBeforeSave or onAfterSave events, then you should implement a manual save datasource instead of an autosave one and call the client side datasource.saveChanges() with a call back function to initiate your client datasource reload. If you are running a server function that gets initiated from the client via google.script.run then you can implement .withSuccessHandler() and .withFailureHandler() functions on the client to provide a call back. You should provide more detail relating to your circumstances in order to provide a relevant answer.

The question title says default values. So the onAttach is appropriate for setting a value and this is the question. How do I write widget.value = object to set a default value. What is the object syntax that defines the data element.

You're missing an important point here. I'm not saying that the onAttach event is not appropriate for setting a default value generally speaking. However, it is in this context. Your widget options are based on a different datasource than your form datasource, therefore when your widget attaches your options array is in fact empty, unless you previously loaded the datasource that your options are based on. Otherwise, when the widget first attaches it will call the load action on the datasource that the options are based on. Anyway I have a possible solution below.

Seems like the token is acquired for some built-in API. You need to make sure the resource for the API is set to your API's client id / app id URI. The aud claim in the token doesn't seem like a client id for one of your APIs.
Correct. Right now I am testing the generation of token from APIM Developer Portal
Roles are only included in tokens that are meant for the app that defined those roles.
The App ID in the token is the same App ID for which the roles are defined in the manifest
The audience (aud) needs to be that, the appid claim doesn't matter.
Aha. So if a PowerApp is invoking these APIs using some connector which will also have an internal aud, there's no way to retrieve app role in the backend API?
No. If the app acquires the access token *for the API* (specifies resource/scope to be that API), the access token will contain the roles.
We are receiving aud as `https://management.core.windows.net/` from PowerApp even if the resource is our `AAD App ID URI` and scope is `openid`
Don't know about PowerApps, sorry. The PowerApp is requesting a token for Azure Resource Management then, which is not what you want.

Your param_Property, what is the type? Is it string, number, list{string}, list{number}, etc.? If that parameter is a list type parameter then I have found doing a logical evaluation against null doesn't work a lot of the time because the default for a list type parameter appears to be [], i.e. an empty array, instead of null. So your logical evaluation might need to be changed to `param_Property.length === 0` or `param_Property.length > 0`.

Most AM widgets are static elements and therefore do not allow dynamic editing per say. What you can do instead is build your own dynamic 'tabs layout' element by accessing your DOM tree via `document.appendChild()` for example and then looping over each of your datasources and again using document to append all elements that you wish to display within each tab when each datasource loads. I presume most people will not want to spend the amount of time to code this so the other alternative would be to add all the necessary tabs and hide them if they are not needed.

The logic you are using is forcing to create duplicates. If you want to update something, then don't create a new record. Instead just update the old record. If you create a new record, then don't assign an old record `Unique` to the new one.

Never mind my earlier comment. I think what you want to happen is if the save record function fails then you want the catch statement to execute which will log your already existing record 'dname' field in the console. Keep in mind that unlike regular apps script, Logger will not work in AM, you actually have to use console.log on server in AM. Also, unlike Apps Script, any actions involving Server API will throw an error on the line where it is first encountered, so the saveRecords throws the error due to duplicate record and the catch portion is never executed.

Just put all the information in your calculated model.

Ditto on @Morfinismo comment. You can include the extra fields in your calculated model and either pull all SQL model records in and than match ID via indexOf() function when generating each line of your calculated model or just run a query against your SQL model by ID match for each line of your calculated model. I’d suggest pulling all records and matching via indexOf() because line item queries are more ‘expensive’ from an execution time aspect, index function will execute way faster.

Many ways to approach this, but the easiest is have your persons table, if you wish to filter this then apply the filter in the datasource's query script with a query of `query.filters.PrimaryEmail._equals() = Session.getActiveUser().getEmail()` then in your panel where you have the persons table make sure the panel datasource is set to 'persons' and drag a new table into this panel with datasource as `persons: vehicles (relation)`. Also make sure to prefetch vehicles in your persons datasource.
Where does `query.filters.PrimaryEmail._equals() = Session.getActiveUser().getEmail()` go? The datasource query script must return an array of records. *Prefetch* is a big help, Thanks!

That filter goes in your datasource query script (server) for persons, but only if you need persons filtered based on the current user. If you need all/several persons returned then don’t apply the filter.

Maybe I misunderstood your question. I suppose if you want two tables, one showing all vehicles and the other only showing vehicles the current user is assigned to, then you should probably go with two separate datasources in your vehicles model.
Can you show the formula you're using please? It looks like it didn't get added correctly

Call one 'AllVehicles' and the other 'UserVehicles' or whatever suits your needs. Have both datasources set to automatically load. On the AllVehicles datasource leave the query builder active and don't enter anything.

On the UserVehicles datasource change it to query script and enter `query.filters.PrimaryEmail._equals() = Session.getActiveUser().getEmail();` in the case that there is no relation between persons and vehicles, or `query.filters.Persons.PrimaryEmail._equals() = Session.getActiveUser().getEmail();` in the case that there is a relation between persons and vehicles. Then add `return query.run();` on the second line of your query script.

I think that you are actually running into concurrent executions, meaning you set your widget value in the onAttach event, the code immediately moves on to reloading the datasource and updating the binding on the widget at the same time, with one beating out the other. Things you could try instead of `widget.value = new Date()` for the widget onAttach is `widget.datasource.query.parameters.expected = new Date()` or you could bind the parameter in the datasource itself to the widget and then autoload the datasource. See if either of those work.

Yes, but I don't necessarily like just hiding elements like a table row, because the hidden table row record would still be stored in `datasource.items`. At this point in time your choices are to either use the JS function `setTimeout(function() {widget.datasource.load();}, 2000)`, which I don't always like either because you cannot accurately predict how much time it takes for the record to update. You may switch the datasource to 'Manual Save' mode and implement `widget.datasource.saveChanges(function() {widget.datasource.load()})`. Or do update server side with success handler.

As far as a date field goes, the date is always stored as a date object as you presented in your example. When using a date field to present in the client, the default format is in YYYY-MM-DD at least in the US. To change this format client side you can use #formatDate() transformer at the end of your date object. So for a label binding this would look like `@datasource.item.YourDateField#formatDate(yyyy/MM/dd)`. For displaying the year only you can use JS `.getFullYear()`, so in a binding this might look like `(@datasource.item.YourDateField).getFullYear()`.
Expanding on @MarkusMalessa comment, you can also use the binding transformer to get only the year `@datasource.item.YourDateField#formatDate(yyyy)`

@MarkusMalessa unfortunatly I'm getting the date as a user input not a binding. So when I get the user input in the client with ```button.root.descendants.dateBox.value```, I'm getting the date in the format mentioned in the question. I tried to format the date to yyyy-mm-dd in the client but can't get it to work

So your only options here are to do `button.root.descendants.dateBox.value.toLocaleDateString()`, but that will give you M/D/YYYY. The `button.root.descendants.dateBox.value.getFullYear()` will still work to get just the year. Alternatively you can look at JS/Jquery libraries that format date objects and use those in your external resources section and then implement those in your client code.

But you will also want to keep in mind that any of the JS date functions will either return a string or a number and anything you want to do with this will no longer be a date object so you cannot use any date functions on those return values anymore.

It would seem that your datasource 'global' is most likely not loaded client side. Even if you set your datasource to 'auto load' that does not mean that the datasource will actually get loaded, it only means that it will automatically load when a page or other element is set to the datasource that it will just load by itself, but you still need something in your app that actually loads this datasource. I would suggest loading this datasource in your app startup script or maybe instead of using a global var inside a datasource just use page properties instead.

That is because the data binding does not take effect during the onInputChange event, the input has to loose focus (i.e. click outside, hit tab or enter key) in order for the binding to complete. However, there is a way to circumvent this and have the onIputChange event complete this binding. All you have to do is enter the following in the onInputChange: `widget.value = event.target.value; widget.datasource.load();`.

In App Maker the only place to use SQL queries of the type you are thinking of is in a calculated SQL model. Anywhere else you would need to use a combination of query scripts or query builders and then do aggregations via JS, which would require many more lines of code then a SQL query. I would check out the documentation here https://developers.google.com/appmaker/models/cloudsql#calculated_sql_models.

May I inquire why you are working with login/logout pages? App Maker appliations work off of Google logins and are only available to individuals within the same domain as the application is published in. So unless you are using logins to connect to an external service of sorts a login/logout is not required. There is a way to set different startup pages, however there is a hard set startup page and then you could use a user table where the user can select a start page and you can select that start page via the app start up script by doing a query. However this would not work for your purpose.

Datasource properties function much in the same way as query filters, i.e. they are unique to each session and therefore each user. Therefore it is more dependent on how you assign this property that points to each user's 'current place'. If it is based on a record from another model for example and each time a query is run against that model and it points to the last created record, then of course this would not work because it would point to the same record for all users.

Ok, I get it now. So since your residents list is set to ‘Units: Residents (Relation)’ you cannot use a query on that list unfortunately because App Maker does not support direct relation filtering. There is a feature request for that functionality but it has not been addressed. The workaround is to create a separate Residents datasource that gets prefiltered on the related units Id and reloads each time a different item is selected in units. This is actually quiet easy to set up.

So what is it you are wanting to use in your case? The example shows possibilities of doing it on the fly or using a calculated datasource. Either would work, you just need to prefetch your relations in your car brand datasource and then sum/subtract your relevant values. Doing this for a calculated datasource you would set a key parameter and feed that key to the calculated DS and run a query where your inventory.carcompany.id._equals = key parameter and reload this DS and feeding it a new key in the company on item change client script.

Based on the solution you came up with for your other question for totaling items you would just want to run your query against car companies instead and prefetch your inventory relation and then do the totaling against the related inventory records.

Deprecated means that the function is in the process of being replaced by something new and often better, so if you use a deprecated function you can not be sure if it will work in the future ... it might but also might be not so its recommended to use the new one to be sure :)

The replacement is already available and is what they refer to as the relation API which is specific to app maker. The documentation here https://developers.google.com/appmaker/models/relations gives you a general idea of how to use it, and I am sure you are probably already using it. Since these are SQL tables we are talking about, the FK field will still be available, however it will only be able to be accessed through calculated SQL datasources. Otherwise, wherever you may have a reference to `YourTable.YourRelation_fk` will essentially have to be replaced with `YourTable.YourRelation.Id`.

It does in fact work; however, trying to clear filter for just that field without using the `._in' is not an option apparently. Just trying to clear that field filter specifically.

Unfortunately App Maker was not built with the functionality to only clear filters on specific fields. The only way to get that accomplished is to set the input value(s) to null, in which case if you reload the datasource any previous filter will be reset to no value for that filter which is the same as ignoring that filter. So you would either need to manually deselect all options, or maybe introduce a button next to the specific widget that would do `widget.value = null` or `widget.values = []` and then still reload the datasource.

Where and how are you running the function to create the trigger? With App Maker you essentially have to call the server function to create the trigger from your client somewhere and this would need to happen for each of your deployments and your 'Preview'. After testing, I would suggest removing the trigger again otherwise it will continue running it from each of deployments as well as your 'Preview'. Have you actually run your trigger to test it? I don't see an immediate problem with your code, so I would suggest actually running your code first. For testing I would change the frequency.

You actually need to call the function createTimeDrivenTriggers() from like a button in the UI by doing `google.scripts.run.createTimeDrivenTriggers()`. Otherwise all you have is the function but the trigger will actually never be created. Then you should also have a button in the UI that will delete the trigger.
Hm, ok thank you. Why is it necessary to delete the trigger? We're trying to make this process (checking for upcoming expirations) as automatic as possible.
The ipad is Gsuite managed. It is likely that is the sorce of not getting to the camera. Thanks.

You would delete the trigger if it by chance would no longer be needed, or as stated during testing periods you don't want the trigger to stay active on a test deployment or in your 'Preview' because it would continually run until it is deleted. So even if your trigger function does not actually process any records, your project would still invoke the function thereby consuming resources against your project. I would suggest looking at the App Maker sample app for triggers if you have not already. https://developers.google.com/appmaker/samples/triggers

If you only named an App Maker widget 'snapshot' and then try to reference that widget by using getElementById() then it does not find that widget in the DOM because app maker widgets don't have an id attribute unless you added that attribute via code. You are missing an important concept here. App Maker does not have a command line interface to be able to run the create trigger function. Therefore, you have to run the function via google.script.run one time from the client to actually create the trigger. Once you have done this, the trigger is part of your project and will continually run automatically. Then the only time the trigger would need to be kicked off manually is if you were to delete it and needed to be created again. Have you checked out the example application for this?

Which line specifically is causing the error? The issue is because whatever variable you're calling `forEach()` on is not an array, so either `aErrors` or `error.fieldErrors`

One of oError, error.pageErrors ,error.fieldErrors or aErrors is not an array, so it does not have the forEach method... I'm certain you are getting more info in your error than just "forEach is not a function"

Be more specific about the error message. There are various positions in your code that could throw an error. `forEach` is a method of the `Array` prototype; the apparent naming convention in the code suggests that `oError` at least is _not_ a JS Array. Check with `typeof oError` and `Array.isArray(oError)`. And check on the other apparent array variables.

We have a file with 30K records which we split into 5K batch size use Bulk Upsert Operation. We can expect that file may contain records with duplicates where the record details can change from 1st records to nth records. As of now, we are filtering just to pick the last unique record.
